id: Boy and girl suffer serious burns in explosion at Queenscliff caravan park
paragraph:
Updated 
    
      November 13, 2018 11:53:12
    
Two high-school aged children have suffered serious burns after a portable camp stove exploded on a school camp at a caravan park in Queenscliff, south-west of Melbourne.Paramedics were called to the park off the Bellarine Highway about 8:00pm when the stove, which runs on methylated spirits, exploded.The Education Department said the students were from the Ballarat Specialist School."We take this matter very seriously and a full investigation will take place to understand how this occurred," a department spokesperson said.School principal Karen Biggelar said she was "shocked" by the news."Our thoughts are with the students and their families during this difficult time," she said."The school will do everything we can to support the family, friends and the community."In a statement, a spokesperson for the Big4 Beacon Resort caravan park said it was assisting with the investigation into the cause of the incident."We can't comment on the cause of the incident other than to say that there appears to have been an explosion whilst the students were using their own portable methylated fuel cooking equipment," the statement said."Our thoughts and prayers remain with the injured students."We are providing every assistance to the investigators during their enquiries, so we can understand what has occurred as quickly as possible." Paramedics assessed four people at the scene, an Ambulance Victoria spokesperson said.Two of the children — a boy and a girl — were flown to the Alfred Hospital with serious burns.The girl was initially in a serious condition with burns to her face, legs and arms, while the boy suffered serious burns to his chest and legs.This morning, both were reported to be in stable conditions.Another boy and girl were released from Geelong University Hospital after being treated for superficial burns to their hand and leg burns.
